captions.text:
Hello and welcome to this SciShow Quick Question
where we answer questions the internet asks.

The following was asked on my tumblr a while
back: "If I weigh 99 pounds and I eat one

pound of nachos, am I 1% nacho?"
Sounds like not a very complicated question,

but it turns out to be, like, super complicated,
because buried in this question are a number
of other, bigger questions.

First: what is nachos? We can safely say that
this is a plate of nachos, invented by the

way in Mexico for Americans. It is not a traditional
Mexican dish.

So this is nachos, and this is me. If I put
this, mmmm. Now the nachos are inside of me,

but are they still nachos? What about after
my digestive system dissolve them into a mushy

acidic goo, are they nachos then? I would
venture to say, that like if you took what

was in my stomach an hour after I ate nachos
and put it on a plate, zero people out of

7 billion would call that nachos. However
for the sake of argument, let's say that the

atoms and molecules that comprise the nachos
are still nachos after you masticate and begin
to digest them.

In that case the other question is: what is
"you"? If I put this ping pong ball in my

mouth, is it me now? It is not, it's just
a ping pong ball in my mouth. But what if

I swallow the ping pong ball, which I will
not, by the way, be doing, would it then be

part of me? I think we'd get various answers
here, but I'm gonna venture to say that no,

it's not part of me.
Likewise if you weigh 99 pounds and you eat

a one pound lump of copper, I'd tend to say
that you're not 1% copper. In fact, your digestive

system is sort of not inside you, it's just
a long complicated tightly controlled tube

of outside, that runs through your inside.
When embryos first develop, one of the first

things they do is punch a hole down the middle
spherical cluster of cells, making that cluster

a doughnut shape. That middle hole is of course
outside the embryo, and that hole becomes

the digestive system. But if you take out
all the stuff in your digestive system there's

a lot of stuff that isn't you, including the
several kilograms of bacteria that live inside

your gut. By mass, the average human is about
3% gut bacteria.

In the end though, after digestion, about
a third of your nachos will never have left

your digestive system, and they will be in
your feces within a day or two. The rest of

the atoms and molecules will be breaking down
more slowly to feed you, some of them expelled

in your urine and feces, others expelled in
the carbon dioxide that you exhale.

The truly amazing thing is that by simple
virtue of the fact that there are so many

atoms and molecules in a single pound of nachos,
some of those atoms will remain with you forever,

ensuring that you are at least some percent
nacho for the rest of your life.

Thank you for watching this SciShow Quick
Question, and an extra special thanks to our

Subbable subscribers, without whom I would
not have been able to answer this question,

and how could we have afforded the nachos!?
If you have any questions you would like us

to answer, we're on Facebook and Twitter and
down in the comments below. Don't forget to
go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

comments.author: Lord Mordekaiser

comments.text:
It's kinda late now, but the answer is basically this:  "I seem to be a 
verb." (R. Buckminster Fuller)  We are not things.  We are processes. 
 Whatever solid identity you think you have is just a snapshot of a 
temporary arrangement of vibrating energies, a rolling subset of everything 
around you and passing through you.  Ultimately, of course, everything is 
information-energy exchange; or, more immediately if you still insist on 
thinking of matter as made up of "things":  "We are star-stuff" (C. Sagan) 
or "We are literally stardust" (Neil deGrasse Tyson).

Hydrogen literally formed out of pure energy in the early universe.  All 
the rest of the atoms in our bodies were made by quantum-tunneling and 
nuclear fusion in the heart of a star.  You are a living supernova 
incarnate!  Don't forget to be awesome, because that is how you got 
started:)﻿
comments.author: rendilkraesin

comments.text:
+SciShow Before I even begin to look at the comments here, which I am 
curious about for several reasons, I want to mention something I was 
surprised you didn't bring up at all, as I am guessing it is probably why 
the question was asked. That is, the question of being partially 
"genetically nacho", whatever exactly that would mean. You see, I recall a 
debate years ago in which a theist argued that a cloud missed being a 
watermelon by 3%. The argument was of course a comparison to the 
approximate percentage of DNA sequence matching between the human genome 
and the chimpanzee genome.

Fact is, there is no DNA sequence for growing a cloud, so in that sense it 
missed being a watermelon by 100%. The argument stated as a premise that a 
watermelon was 97% water and a cloud was 100% water, but of course we know 
that a cloud is not 100% water, and a chimpanzee is made of the same basic 
chemistry as humans are, as is a plate of nachos. Well, not the plate... 
but the nachos. So one could argue that no matter whether you eat nothing 
but nachos your whole life or no nachos at all in your whole life, you are 
100% nachos by that definition. It's simply a bad definition, because as 
you pointed out, nobody in their right mind is going to call a bunch of 
organic mush nachos regardless if it used to be. think anyone 

Of course, if a cloud has any DNA in it, which probably every NATURAL cloud 
in Earth's sky does, it is incidental and would not stop the cloud from 
being a cloud if it was removed. Likewise, if there were a way to remove 
all the DNA from a plate of nachos without otherwise changing anything else 
about them, while the result would be slightly less nutritious, I don't 
think anyone sane would try to argue that the result was no longer 
nachos... although people who knew the procedure had been done may be 
hesitant to eat them.

Also, in the case of the claim about the cloud having missed being a 
watermelon by 3%, I propose the following mental experiment to check the 
validity of the statement. Imagine a cloud in the sky having 3% of its 
water removed. Would that make it a watermelon? If the only thing keeping 
it from being a watermelon is that the watermelon had 3% less water, it 
should. What if you tried it with a bucket of pure water that weighed the 
exact same amount as a watermelon after 3% of its water was removed. Would 
that make it a watermelon? Of course not. What if you removed 3% of the 
water from a cloud or from a bucket of water and replaced it with an equal 
weight of something else... like for example watermelon cells... would it 
be a watermelon then? Obviously not... although if you did it with pure 
water and added watermelon seeds, the genome contained in the mixture would 
be 100% watermelon genome... but the water itself would still just be 
water.﻿

Sooo... A dinosaur eats a plant, that dinosaur gets eaten by another 
dinosaur, that dinosaur dies, and gets broken down to inorganic compounds, 
plants use those inorganic compounds to grow...  Cycle continues, several 
mass die offs happen....
We are part dinosaur!﻿

comments.text:
If you have eaten nachos, then parts of you were also once parts of nachos. 
That doesn't mean you're x% nachos. For you to be x% nachos, that x% would 
have to actually be composed of corn chips covered in nacho toppings, 
rather than some of the chemical constituents of nachos broken down, 
rearranged, and dispersed throughout your body.﻿
